articleContentTranslated: â€œThe football association and its president Claudio Tapia feel deep pain over the death of our legend, Diego Armando Maradona. You will always be in our hearts, â€tweeted the association.

The Argentine government ordered a three-day state mourning. Maradona was considered one of the best footballers in history. In 1986 the excellent technician led Argentina to the second world title in its history in Mexico.

With SSC Napoli, Maradona won the Italian championship and the UEFA Cup twice. After his active career, the Argentine was also team boss in his home country, but off the field, the eccentric superstar also made headlines with excessive drug and alcohol consumption.

Photo gallery with 9 pictures Unforgettable are the "hand of God" with which he scored against England at the 1986 World Cup, or his goal of the century after an unbelievable dribble in the same game.

But the pictures of the round Maradona with bleached hair, which appeared years later, are also unforgettable. He failed not only as a team boss, but also as a TV presenter, spent weeks in hospitals, had his stomach made smaller and several times just missed death.
Mourning for Diego Maradona The Argentine football legend died of a heart attack on Wednesday around a month after his 60th birthday in his home in Tigre, north of Buenos Aires.

Recently back in the hospital Maradona had recently survived a hospital stay. He was discharged from a hospital in the suburbs of Buenos Aires on November 11, just over a week after the operation because of a cerebral hemorrhage.
The former superstar initially talked about emotional stress, anemia and dehydration. The tests then found bleeding between the meninges and the brain.

Maradona survived what was possibly the most difficult moment of his life, said his lawyer Matias Morla at the time. Maradona is willing to rehabilitate herself because of personal problems: "Maradona will be around for a while." A few days later, Maradona died of a heart attack in his house.

The legend began in the Villa Fiorito settlement on the outskirts of Buenos Aires, where "El Pibe de Oro" (the golden boy) was discovered early by the first division club Argentinos Juniors.
As a twelve-year-old ball boy, he is said to have offered the spectators more entertainment than the first team with his cabinet pieces during the half-time breaks.

At the age of 15 he made his debut in the first division, at 16 he was a national player, at 17 top scorer and at the age of 19 for the first time South America's footballer of the year. Maradona shied away from comparison with Pele Reporters at the time wanted to know whether he was the new Pele know him.
â€œI'm Maradona, not a new thing. I just want to be Maradona, â€replied the youngâ€œ Diegito â€. And he succeeded without a doubt: that his life path was incomparable.
In the beginning, many things went well. In 1982 Maradona moved from Boca Juniors to FC Barcelona for a record fee, but he only rose to demigod two years later.
For another record transfer, I went to SSC Napoli, not to the big clubs in northern Italy, but to the mocked fast relegation in the despised south.

"Italy's sewer" sound like Juve or Milan fans during the duel. This is where the transformation began. Maradona rose higher and higher, in 1987 and 1990 he led Napoli to the only championships in the club's history to date.

When he was greeted, more than 70,000 fans had greeted him in the Stadio San Paolo, and later people kept hanging around in front of his door. Once a nurse allegedly stole a blood sample from him and brought it to church.

Maradona could handle the hype as long as he played soccer, he got better and better on the pitch. The Neapolitans still revere him like a saint. Problems off the field â€œOn the pitch, life becomes unimportant.
The problems, all of this becomes unimportant, â€he said in the documentaryâ€œ Diego Maradona â€. Off the pitch he became just as uncontrollable as for his opponents.
He fell for cocaine (â€œOne line - and I felt like Supermanâ€), sometimes went around the houses from Sunday to Wednesday, only to sweat it all out again until the next game on the weekend.

His national team career ended at the 1994 World Cup because of a doping ban by the World Football Association (FIFA). â€œDiego had a life like a dream. And like a nightmare, â€said his long-time fitness trainer Fernando Signorini.

"I think he thinks he is a god and that could be one of the reasons for his problems," said Hector Pezzella, the director of the Guemes Clinic in Buenos Aires, where Maradona was treated in 2007, many years ago.
The exceptional player has never spared himself. "He lives every moment as if it were his last," emphasized Signorini. â€œOnce Diego is gone, he will be loved even more.
